subject: Add service cache for readingData()
commitMessage:
Add service cache for readingData()

This change caches ipmi::getService call in readingData(), similar to
what ServiceCache is doing, in order to reduce repeated service lookups.

Before this change, the reading of every sensor involved two DBus calls:
1) GetObject() on ObjectMapper and 2) Get() on the object corresponding
to the sensor.

With this change, GetObject() is cached, saving some time.

Tested with an Aspeed BMC, saw correct results and a bit of speedup.

Signed-off-by: Sui Chen <suichen@google.com>
Change-Id: Ib4cbc00b4118c84cad4d4b317caccf5c92b36fcb

Patch Set 6:

(4 comments)

This is weird and I'm not sure that I like it, now that I've read the diff and think I understand it a little better.

It seems really odd to be associating a cached value onto a POD member. It seems weird to be doing that in a way which violates constness. It especially seems weird when we already have a place for caches like this to go. What happens when we decide we need to invalidate the cache on all our sensors for some reason? Can't do it easily, and nobody would be able to find it to do it anyways.

Why don't you add a map<sensor id, service object> to ServiceCache instead?

Patch Set 9:

(4 comments)

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> (4 comments)
> 
> This is weird and I'm not sure that I like it, now that I've read the diff and think I understand it a little better.
> 
> It seems really odd to be associating a cached value onto a POD member. It seems weird to be doing that in a way which violates constness. It especially seems weird when we already have a place for caches like this to go. What happens when we decide we need to invalidate the cache on all our sensors for some reason? Can't do it easily, and nobody would be able to find it to do it anyways.
> 
> Why don't you add a map<sensor id, service object> to ServiceCache instead?

I had removed the changes to the ipmi::sensor::Info, so the "mutable" keyword is not needed.

The cached service names are stored in a newly-created class SensorServiceCache, not in ServiceCache.

The reason ServiceCache is not reused is because:
1) ServiceCache only caches one service, so using it will encounter the same "how to invalidate all cached service names at one time" problem; and
2) ServiceCache is meant to be used to issue method calls, replacing bus.new_method_call with newMethodCall(). To compare, readingData() calls getDbusProperty which in turn calls bus.new_method_call. Leveraging ServiceCache::newMethodCall will require modifying getDbusProperties specifically for readingData(), but I'm not sure if this is the best practice.

Please advise .. thanks!

Patch Set 13:

prior to this change, this application supported a modular system design where sensors can be physically added/removed from the system (at least, that was the intent when it was written years ago, because IBM has such systems).  Am I missing something or does this cache assume a static sensor configuration?  How will the cache be invalidated?

Patch Set 13:

(4 comments)

> Patch Set 13:
> 
> prior to this change, this application supported a modular system design where sensors can be physically added/removed from the system (at least, that was the intent when it was written years ago, because IBM has such systems).  Am I missing something or does this cache assume a static sensor configuration?  How will the cache be invalidated?

I don't think this cache will change that. This is just keeping a cache of service names for paths to reduce the calls to the mapper. You still need to know what sensors to look up, which is done outside the scope of this change.

Patch Set 16:

> Patch Set 13:
> 
> (4 comments)
> 
> > Patch Set 13:
> > 
> > prior to this change, this application supported a modular system design where sensors can be physically added/removed from the system (at least, that was the intent when it was written years ago, because IBM has such systems).  Am I missing something or does this cache assume a static sensor configuration?  How will the cache be invalidated?
> 
> I don't think this cache will change that. This is just keeping a cache of service names for paths to reduce the calls to the mapper. You still need to know what sensors to look up, which is done outside the scope of this change.

Thanks for the hints on modifiable sensors --- I understand the concern here, and I see that the Object Mapper mechanism enables dynamically adding/removing sensors by maintaining a mapping between the sensor's human-readable name to its monitoring daemon's DBus object.

I saw a typical ObjectMapper call (by ipmi::getService) may be as follows:
Input:  ("/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/cpu0temp", "xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Value")
Output: dict("xyz.openbmc_project.Hwmon-(Some ID).Hwmon1", ...)

In other words, ObjectMapper says "cpu0temp is in that Hwmon object." As far as I'm aware, dbus-monitor may serve the same purpose as Hwmon does.

The reading of all sensors eventually go through the getDbusProperty() function, since the readings are maintained as properties of their respective DBus objects. If a sensor gets added/removed, or an Hwmon process gets restarted, getDbusProperty() will encounter an error, and the resultant raw value would be zero. We can use this to detect changes in sensors during run time. The current version of the patchset demonstrates this idea ... I haven't been able to reliabliy test this behavior though, because the number in the hwmon DBus object name seems to be constant when a reading daemon is terminated and restarted.

Alternatively, a more elegant solution might be to listen to the "Hello" events emitted by newly-created DBus peers, and if the new peer appears to be a sensor daemon, clear the cache. Does this make sense to you?

Addressed the comments; will try to test how the sensor reading function handles run-time changes in the sensors' DBus object names.

Patch Set 17:

Your idea is sound. However, I'm concerned about the cache getting out of sync with ongoing configuration changes over time. I know that entity-manager broadcasts a notification on D-Bus that the sensor configuration has changed, when it pushes out changes to the various dbus-sensors programs. Perhaps this notification can also be listened to, in order to properly react to changes by invalidating the previous cache? I'm not sure how this works, exactly, but I'm wondering if there's other ways of recognizing changes that you would also need to be able to react to. Maybe you can use D-Bus itself to receive notifications from objects of interest, and use those notifications to know when to invalidate?
Set Work In Progress
Abandoned
Please explain why you need to use mutable keyword.
The mutable is needed because cachedService is modified in readingData(const Info& sensorInfo), where the structure is passed in as a const reference.
Shouldn't you just pass it into readingData as a reference instead, then?

As far as I know this one is one typical usage of the "mutable" keyword (with a cached service name, the object is "logically" constant, but "physically" non-constant, and "mutable" sets an exception for the cached value in a "const" scope), but I think it is also okay to remove "const" from readingData so someone reading the code would be watchful for any changes to the structure.
I think in general it's not preferred to use "catch (...)". You should type and name the exception you catch, so you can output some information about it if necessary.
Added a logging statment.
Hm, I don't think this is a good idea. We are OK with using goto to do some cleanup and return, in some cases when the cleanup is nontrivial, but this is not a good place to use goto.
Switched to a for loop.

spurious newline.

You can check for these kinds of things by staging your changes via 'git add -p' which gives you an overview of each chunk you're adding to the diff.

Yeah, the way you're using this, you shouldn't be taking sensorInfo as const anymore. Please get rid of 'mutable' and pass in sensorInfo by reference.
Reverted to the original code flow by using the newly-defined SensorServiceCache so no need to access sensorInfo.cachedService now.
Hmmm. The catch (...) came in the original code... I don't like it, but it's not your fault, I guess.
Added logging to this code block.

Because this is getting used by the ipmi provider libraries (libipmi20.so and possibly others), this should really be a part of libipmid.so.

I would suggest adding it to libipmid/utils.cpp and then add a function declaration there as well so you don't have to 'extern' declare it in the sensor files that use it.

One last thing, I would prefer returning a reference to the object rather than a pointer. Then it is clear that it will never be NULL.
Using an iterator to make changes to the map now.
